Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 11:23AM FightnF8 wrote: Cynthia: I think your reaction is totally normal considering all you are going through. We all have our moments that we breakdown and we all have our moments where we feel strength. Some of us take prescriptions to help us through the tough times, some of us don't. It all depends on what YOU feel is right for you which none of us can tell. Personally I take Ativan to slow my mind from the constant anxiety. As far as the car crash my opinion is NOT to rely on the insurance company. I was in a wreck and ended up with a neck fusion and a year later shoulder surgery for pain that wouldn't go away. There are attorneys available who you don't have to pay unless you get a settlement (aside from the fees for filing documents in court) that can help you immensely. I used to work in a law office and not all of these attorneys fall under the slimy descriptions they are given. One of the tough things about our diagnosis is that it takes time to heal from the news. Like anything else i.e., broken heart, loss of a loved one, it does get better over time. It is definitely a roller coaster with the tests, results, and treatments but it is doable. I always remember all the reasons why I want to live and that makes it easier to deal with the rest.  Hoping you feel better soon but until then cry your tears as much as you need to.

Posts.Content: FightnF8 wrote: Initial diagnosis was November 2009 with mets in several bones and bone marrow.  Had chemo for 6 months. Clear scan. Took Aromasin. Had bone scan, more mets so today I started chemo again.  Taxol/Avastin with Aredia.  It was a bizarre day! First I'll back up one day.  I had a PETscan yesterday and didn't get out of there until 3:00.  After not eating all day I thought I would treat myself to a Wendy's hamburger.  I might eat fast food 3 times a year and usually those times are after tests where I can't eat.  Within 15-20 minutes I had the worst diarrhea and vomiting until 2:30 this morning. What a crappy night....literally!! Woke up today and thought I might not have chemo.  I called the on-call doc in the evening when I was supposed to take my Roids.  He said not to take them because I would just throw them up. Ended up having chemo today and actually feel better now than when I went in.  Got my hydration back!  Then about an hour before I was done the strangest thing happened. A woman on Taxol (my chemo) had a SEVERE allergic reaction.  She almost died.  The nurses and onc were doing CPR on her and called 911 to get the medics there to take her to emergency. Scary stuff!  But I'll tell you what those nurses and doc were quick and worked like a well oiled machine.  When it was all over they kept coming over to see if I (and the others around her) was ok and giving hugs.  There were many tears.  They were so caring.  I just got a call from the nurse to see how I am doing now that I'm home.  People who work in oncology are a pretty incredible breed!! It has been a Freaky Friday and now I'm ready to just chill and go to bed early!!  Women are like teabags....the more hot water they get into the stronger they become! Dx 11/19/2009, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2011 05:04AM FightnF8 wrote: Well have had 6 treatments of Halaven now....2 weeks on 1 week off.  I have been beyond tired for the entire time until this past week.  The chemo nurses think I am still recuperating from my Hawaii and New York trip.  The onc agrees.  I'm hoping they are right and the Halaven is still working!  My tumor marker was above 1,000 and is now at 568.   Yeah.  For the FIRST time since November 2009 my bone and bone marrow mets are .... dare I say .... STABLE.  I have met the stable boy for the first time and I'm not turning him loose.  I do have some abandonement issues but I am hoping they will pass. On another note (and I believe I'm not the only one in this scenario) I do have some progression in a new area.  There are some tumors in the nodes around my lungs.  We are keeping an eye on them to make sure they don't get much bigger or we will have to change chemo. It's interesting to have "diffuse sclerotic metastatic disease throughout the bones" appear stable. It seems like an oxymoron to me.  I want them just to be gone (as in disappear) and if I am understanding correctly they are still there but have now suddenly stopped growth, even though they are still all over the place.  Am I asking too much??  Looks like I also have a paratracheal node growth. Guess that could be why I have this whisky and cigar voice that causes me to keep telling my onc I could moonlight as a phone sex person.  One of my friends calls me Demi Moore. Dang, if only I looked like her too!! So I guess we take the good with the bad and just hope to buy more time.  Since my tiredness got better I asked for a break from chemo but it is not the right time for that right now since I have progression.  Dang.  Sometimes I just want a month or two off but my bugger is too aggressive whenever I'm breaking.  I just try to hold onto the good part of this and hope the bad follows the same pattern. The fight sometimes gets old when you have nothing but chemo to rely on.  The AI's never worked for me even though I'm estrogen positive.  Have been a fluke my whole life that way.  Been on 7 chemos so far.  Hope Halaven hangs for awhile.  I had a good 6 months on Abraxane before this.  How do our bodies, minds, and spirits keep doing this over and over?  We are some sort of strong women around here!!!  Give yourself a big HOOYA for that!

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 06:04PM FightnF8 wrote: I will be receiving my check this week.  I was told it does not affect SSDI, it does not affect my LTD, and the reason they cash out a percentage and not the whole amount is that they charge a small interest on the money if you live longer than expected.  I told them charge away, I would be thrilled to live longer than they expect me to!!!  I've also heard you don't pay taxes. Guilt...yep, felt it too.  Still do.  The insurance company called me last Friday to tell me I was approved and the person who signs the approval would not be in until Monday but they would be happy to expedite the check to me.  I told them I was in no hurry, just send it regular mail.  It felt too much like another step in the direction of making this more real yet again. It was almost like I wanted them to turn me down and then maybe this would all be a big mistake. On that note, I will be taking trips with my family this year and paying for my COBRA payments to continue my insurance since I just stopped working.  Good luck to you!!  Do something special for yourself, you certainly deserve it!!!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2012 07:07PM FightnF8 wrote: I am posting for my sister Lorelei, who you all know as "Fighting F8". I am so sad to tell you that my sweet sister passed away peacefully at home yesterday afternoon. She was surrounded by our family who loved her dearly. She was able to visit with many close friends in the week before  her death and we are so grateful for the friends who came and brought a smile to her face. She left instructions on how to log in to this message board and asked me to post that she is an angel now. What I want to say is that she has always been an angel to us.... the most loving, giving person we have known. I was blessed to have her as my sister and best friend for 52 years. Lorelei fought long and hard during her battle with breast cancer. She never gave up, never took off those pink boxing gloves, even during her last weeks. She was an inspiration to so many of us for her courage, strength, and determination. Thank you all for giving her support during her battle. I know you were able to help her in ways that only you understand. It devastated us to watch everything Lorelei has had to endure these past 2 years, but she never gave up hope. She fought her cancer with grace and never lost her sense of humor. I admire my sister more than I can say. We will all miss her and love her forever. Thank you to all her survivor sisters, Lindy

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 08:47PM FightnF8 wrote: Nil: It is good that you are reaching out. That is one step in helping you deal with all of this. You are so young and it is so unfair that your life will change at such a young age. None of us know why we have to go through this and I'm sure we all deal with it in our own unique ways. My mom and my sister have had breast cancer. My first diagnosis came at the age of 44, second at 47 and third (Stage 4) at 50.  When I feel my lowest I try and spend time with people who bring me happiness like my sister or my niece and her family. I have friends I go to lunch with or meet for a movie. Recently I have been having more pain than usual so I have to do things that don't involve being very active. Even a visit and a cup of tea is sometimes helpful. I think it is hard to deal with such a sudden life change. Believe it or not as time passes it gets a little easier to accept. I didn't believe that when somebody here mentioned that to me but it is true. If you search through some of this discussion board here you will see many women have survived for many years with cancer in their bones. Your hope may come and go but hold onto it. Life is precious, don't spend it worrying about losing it spend it living. Blessing to you! I'm sure you will receive many prayers from the people on this discussion board. You are much to young to have to deal with this!!!!!

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 12:51PM FightnF8 wrote: Lynn: I am like you.  An information queen.  I want to know everything about everything so I can form the problem and the solution.  Once I know the solution, or something close to the solution, I can deal with the acceptance.  It was a slap in the face for me after I finished 6 months of chemo and 3 months later had to go back for 6 months more (will be finished in December).  I don't even feel like I got a break. So every time I think I don't want chemo as I'm driving to chemo I come up with all the reasons of why I want to be alive.  Since chemo is the only thing that works for me for getting rid of the cancer that is my solution to my problem.  It is not fair, it is not fun and it is not what I dreamt my life would be but it is what it is.  I have absolutely no control of the situation except to say yes to treatment or no.  Since I want to keep on living I say yes.  But I can say no whenever I want and I know it. Maybe not a very good way of handling this fate but it works for me right now.  I always live in the right now and not the yesterdays or tomorrows.  I'm a realist to the core.  It took me some time to get to this point (I was diagnosed Stage IV Nov 09) and it works to more good days than bad ones.  I try and do something fun every day and whenever I feel really bummed I think so what would I be doing differently if I knew I was dying tonight?  Just some thoughts and things that work for me.  I wish the best for you!!  When I'm doing my Friday chemo I'll be thinking of my new GA friend doing her Friday chemo too.

Posts.Content: FightnF8 wrote: Thought I would share some good news with everyone.  I'm heading to New York tomorrow morning at 6:00 a.m.  I will be meeting my sister, her husband and my mom there for a 5-day visit.  My sister and her hubby are in Philly for a convention and my mom is taking the train to New York (she HATES flying!).  I'm flying in a day before them so I can rest after the long flight and ready myself to be an east coast tourist.  I've never been to New York and am looking forward to seeing the big apple!  I hear it is raining all week but we don't care, we are from Oregon. Our plans so far are a carriage ride through the park, see The Jersey Boys, catch a taping of The View on Thursday, take a tour bus through the town and stop wherever we want and have dinner out every night.  It is definitely an expensive trip but isn't that what accelerated benefits are for? A bit of enjoyment while it is available!! Got a great short wig to wear that is actually comfortable (Raquel Welch) and people in chemo thought it was real last week when I wore it for the "wig test".  The trips I have been taking keep me going.  As long as I keep planning fun stuff I have something to look forward to no matter how crappy I feel.  I figure whatever gets me through this is alright!  Women are like teabags....the more hot water they get into the stronger they become! Posts.Content: FightnF8 wrote: I had a little incident at the fair last Friday after chemo.  I met my niece, her husband and kids there and we stopped and got a treat to eat (Fri-Jo's) while walking around.  Before I knew it I was having a major choking issue.  My poor niece probably thought I was a goner! Went in for my neuopogen shot yesterday and told the nurse about it.  She sent me to an ENT doc today.  Guess they don't mess around with the choking/breathing issue.  Had a nice little scope put in my nose (ew!) to look at my throat and learned I have a paralyzed vocal cord.  I wondered why I sounded like I was reliving puberty!!  I guess my new progression of lymph node involvement has pressed upon a nerve that damaged my vocal chord. Dang, if it's not one thing it is another with this damn disease!! On the up side my tumor markers are still going down, down, down with Halaven!!  Kind of worrying that the chemo is not working on my lymph nodes as I have read on the Halaven thread that some of you had it work in some areas but not in others.  Crazy stuff.  Women are like teabags....the more hot water they get into the stronger they become! Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2010 10:31PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:06AM by FightnF8 Cat: I don't mind answering questions at all.  I figure there could be a lurker (like I was at first) too afraid to ask questions but looking for answers.  I did try hormonal therapy....tamoxifan, femara and arimidex. None of them worked for me.  I took tamoxifan for a year and a half (after my first diagnosis of Stage 1) and the others for a few months. It was a hard pill to swallow only being able to have chemo but I figured the alternative was worse.  So far for chemo I have tried Taxol/Avastin, Taxotere/Cytoxan and will begin Gemzar tomorrow.  I have only had one bone marrow.  I asked about having another but there really isn't a point in putting myself through that pain since my tumor marker is up (547), my blood counts screwy, and scan showing progression my little chemo break is over.  I initially lost 20 pounds and my appetite is low but I MAKE myself eat. I figure it helps keep my body in fight mode.  I have some sort of thickness in my colon too and do feel nauseous and like I could vomit so the onc thinks there is some progression there (taking Immodium AD regularly is another clue).  I do still have an arsenal of chemos to try since I can't do hormonal therapy. I hope your liver is ok too!!!  It all just sucks but if I keep my mind planning trips and fun things to do while I am still able to it keeps me going.  I have lots of good friends who come to visit from out of town and lots of local family members so I am very lucky.  Do you have good support around you?  I'm happy to answer anything you ask and feel a kinship with you.  I haven't found anybody else with bone marrow mets.  My onc says it is VERY unusual.  Oh boy, lucky us.  Lets keep in touch!  I'll be thinking of you, sending positive vibes and hoping the best for you!!!!! Lorelei

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2011 11:39AM FightnF8 wrote: You are definitely not alone.  We are here for you and I'm sure there is someone out there you are friends with that wants to help but doesn't now how to approach it.  Nobody who hasn't had this disease can truly understand what we are going through.  We get it.  But those who don't know a lot of times wish to understand and want to help somehow but are clueless what to do.  That is where we come in.  We need to communicate to them what we would like them to know.  Maybe, "Hey can you meet me for lunch after my chemo next week?"  Or go with you to chemo. I have a lot of family support and many friends that love me but I have to communicate to them what I need because they are thinking I am feeling sick and should just leave me alone.  Although I don't like to ask for things, I am learning that it isn't so bad and the time spent with the people I chose to be around has been a positive, sometimes uplifting experience. If you don't have a lot of support of family and friends there is always the, "Treat Yourself LIke a Queen" quote my sister gave me when this all started.  I have passed that quote onto many fighting cancer.  It just means do something nice for yourself when you are feeling down.  Something you wouldn't normall treat yourself to like a foot massage, facial, lunch somewhere delicious....whatever you like to do.  I've been doing the Queen thing for about a year and a half now and it helps whenever I feel really down.  I just say, "That's it, I'm a Queen today." And then I spoil myself somehow. Hope you are feeling better about all of this soon.  We are always here for rants or assistance. You can always take a little of this and leave a little of that of our words of advice and do whatever helps you out and with luck the funk won't last long.

Posts.Content: FightnF8 wrote: A quick synopsis....diagnosed in Nov 09 Stage IV mets extensive to bones and bone marrow.  6 months of taxotere, cytoxin (didn't work).  Three months of aromasin (didn't work).  Started taxol, avastin June 2010.  Now my tumor marker (ca 27.29) is up to 441 from 42 last November.  My latest bone scan showed improvement in ribs, sternum, spine, shoulder but legs are showing mets yet onc thinks it could also be from many neupogen shots so I'm holding off on those this week.  If my tumor marker goes up again at next Friday's appointment then on to a new chemo AGAIN.  It seems like that is a lot of new drugs in a very short time and none of them seem to be working.  I'm thinking there may be more tests in my future or possibly a PETscan??  Would the PETscan show something the bone scan did not?  For some reason my onc did not share my tumor marker number until this past week yet has known it since November.  I think he doesn't like to bombard me with info but filter it and ease it upon me.  I know the tumor markers are not the do all but the number rising is making me nervous.  I worry that it is spreading outside my bones now.  Are there tests they do to see where else it has spread??  I will have many questions for next Friday's appointment.  Argh. Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2010 07:56PM FightnF8 wrote: I remember those roids messing with my head when I took them.  The old hamster wheel in my head spun round and round.   It is a sucky disease to live with and I haven't had it that long, but I have been dealing with some sort of breast cancer for the past 13 years.  What I have learned during that time is that nobody has a guarantee.  I lost my oncologist to a mountain climb when a boulder broke off and hit him and he fell.  I saw him on a Thursday and he died that Sunday.  A perfectly healthy man and an oncologist no less!!  We have one gift....that we know our impending future although not when.  We have the opportunity to appreciate every day, every breath, every moment with the people we love.  His life was taken and he had no idea it was coming.  I wonder if he had words he wished he had said or not said, things he wanted to do but never did.  I'm happy to wake up and have another day and I'm damn well making sure I do something fun that I want to do!

Posts.Content: FightnF8 wrote: I posted a few weeks ago that I was hoping to hold onto my hair for my trip to San Francisco (while being treated with Taxol, Aredia and Avastin) and I did!!  I keep joking that I willed it to stay in and when I get home it will be lying on my pillow.  It survived the trip! I was meeting an old flame I hadn't seen in many, many years.  We were engaged once 30 years ago.  My sister, her husband and I went to dinner with him our first night in town.  I hooked up with him the next day and did the tourist thing.  Then we went to dinner with my sister and her husband and off to see the play Wicked. He got us tickets in the 3rd row center stage.  It was awesome and the highlight of the trip. The next day he and I had breakfast then we all went to a Giants game.  That evening he had to pack for a trip and I met up with an old girlfriend I hadn't seen in over 10 years.  I had so much fun on this trip and forgot about cancer for 3 days.  It was nice to reconnect with some old friends and feel so comfortable with both of them after all of these years. Now that I'm home everyone wants to know if there was a romance.  There was much fun, laughs, good conversation but he did seem a little shocked about my diagnosis.  He hadn't understood what it entailed until we talked about it on this trip.  He thought I would have chemo and be done with this cancer like his dad had been with his cancer. It is a little depressing because before the trip his emails were kind of spiced with hints of romance.  I'm not sure anyone will ever be able to accept this horrible disease and want to be in a relationship too.  Kinda sad about that but I have such a great life I'm not going to complain.  It is just not always easy to be single, deal with losing your hair over and over, and not have someone to just hold you once in awhile when you feel down and make you feel better about yourself. Anyone else go through this?? Women are like teabags....the more hot water they get into the stronger they become! Dx 11/19/2009, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2010 07:57PM FightnF8 wrote: I have shoulder mets right now.  My pain isn't there all the time but I'm having it now.  For me it currently gets worse as the day wears on.  I'm having a bone scan on Tuesday.  I was getting a PETscan every three months but after the last one I started having pain and the PETscan was clear. My onc decided to try a bone scan and it showed a small amount of mets in my shoulder, ribs, hip, spine, clavicle and sternum.  I guess different scans pick up different things.  I have not had a MRI so I'm not sure about that one.  I too am worried since my pain has increased.  I wish you the best!

Posts.Content: FightnF8 wrote: It's been awhile since I have posted anything.  I pop in and read, hover and offer small gestures of hope and support.  Lately I've been feeling at the end of my rope.  Plowing through chemos that stop working, AI's that don't work at all, too much cancer to try radiation, etc.  Cancer spread in the bone marrow is an interesting game to play.  Well I had to make a turn around and decided I was going to spend this year living for great memories. Last weekend my nieces and nephews were all in town and I took them out to dinner, threw on a long wig, got dressed up and after dinner we went to a karaoke bar.  We laughed and stayed out till midnight.  ALL of us had a grand time.  It was on my bucket list to just hang out with all of them since we had not done that before.  Since I don't have kids of my own they have always felt like they were my kids.  What a tremendous memory I have of that evening. In April 13 of us are heading for Maui for 10 days.  It will be another grand time.  In May my sister, her husband, my mom and I will be in New York for 4 days.  In June my nephew is getting married in California and in October another nephew is getting married in Portland.  I am planning to be at ALL of these events with bells on.  Nothing is stopping me from planning and attending.  Even when I feel like crap I talk to my onc about these trips and he says he doesn't highly recommenso much travelling but will have me feeling better when the time comes that I need to go.  He gets it.  . If I don't have something to look forward to I'm in a rut feeling like I'm just hanging out waiting to die.  If I make plans I feel more like I'm spending every day living, not dying.  So off I go.  If I get tired I'll rest.  If I"m in pain I have a pill.  If there is an emergency there are hospitals everywhere.  I'm spending my last year or two having fun!!!  Sometimes I wish I had some matie to spend the fun with but don't think there is any time for that right now. Just working through the bucket list thanks to cashing out my life insurance policy.  I'm not married and my family members do not want me to leave them anything, they just want me to have fun so I am!!  Even when I feel my worst I know I have a plan out there awaiting me to get better.  I'm bound and determined to make all these trips. I had one more planned that didn't quite work out.  My birthday is in March and I wanted to take my sister to see Ellen.  It was IMPOSSIBLE to get tickets (even though they are free).  I tried everything I knew...writing...calling....emailing.  Guess some things are just out of reach.  Maybe we can go another time. Go out and do something fun today!!!  Something that will make you laugh or feel like a kid again. :)   Lorelei  Women are like teabags....the more hot water they get into the stronger they become!
